verses.text: Now when David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had raided the Negev and Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag and burned it with fire.
verses.comment: Ziklag was the city given to David by the Philistines. The Amalekites, old enemies of Israel, attack while David is away. The number three echoes the pattern of restoration in Scripture (Hosea 6:2; Matt. 12:40).

verses.text: They had taken captive the women and all who were in it, both young and old. None was killed, but they carried them off and went their way.
verses.comment: The Amalekites did not kill but took everyone captive. This detail sets the stage for God's mercy and the restoration to come.

verses.text: So David and his men came to the city, and there it was, burned with fire, and their wives, their sons, and their daughters had been taken captive.
verses.comment: This is a moment of total loss—David’s leadership will be tested in the crisis.

verses.text: Then David and the people with him lifted up their voices and wept until they had no strength left to weep.
verses.comment: The intensity of the sorrow here is a reminder of the human cost of war and the compassionate side of leadership (cf. Jesus weeping in John 11:35).

verses.text: David’s two wives were taken captive: Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel.
verses.comment: Scripture often notes the status and location of wives for genealogical and narrative purposes.

verses.text: David was greatly distressed, for the people spoke of stoning him, because the soul of all the people was grieved, every man for his sons and daughters. But David strengthened himself in the LORD his God.
verses.comment: David becomes a model for spiritual leadership: turning to God in crisis, he prefigures the reliance on divine grace rather than human strength, a central spiritual lesson throughout Scripture (cf. 2 Cor. 12:9).

verses.text: Then David said to Abiathar the priest, son of Ahimelech, “Bring me the ephod.” So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
verses.comment: David seeks guidance through the priest and the ephod—showing the vital role of priestly mediation and liturgical acts. This subtle pattern foreshadows Christ’s high priesthood and the importance of ordained mediators in salvation history.

verses.text: David inquired of the LORD, saying, “Shall I pursue this raiding party? Will I overtake them?” The LORD answered him, “Pursue them, for you will surely overtake them and rescue everyone.”
verses.comment: God’s response through sacred inquiry reaffirms the importance of seeking God’s will before acting, a spiritual discipline for all believers.

verses.text: So David set out, he and the six hundred men who were with him. They came to the brook Besor, where those who were left behind stayed.
verses.comment: Six hundred is an echo of Gideon’s small force (Judg. 7), showing God’s strength through the faithful remnant.

verses.text: But David pursued, he and four hundred men, while two hundred stayed behind, too exhausted to cross the brook Besor.
verses.comment: The division of the men sets up a key lesson in God’s economy: both those who fight and those who support share in the reward (see v. 24).

verses.text: They found an Egyptian in the open country and brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink.
verses.comment: Showing mercy to strangers can reveal God’s providence (Heb. 13:2; see Good Samaritan, Luke 10:33-37).

verses.text: They gave him a piece of a fig cake and two clusters of raisins. When he had eaten, his spirit revived, for he had not eaten bread or drunk water for three days and three nights.
verses.comment: Hospitality restores life. The motif of three days and nights subtly foreshadows Christ’s resurrection (Matt. 12:40).

verses.text: Then David said to him, 'To whom do you belong, and where are you from?' He said, 'I am an Egyptian, servant to an Amalekite. My master left me behind because I fell sick three days ago.'
verses.comment: The servant’s abandonment underscores the mercilessness of the Amalekites, highlighting David’s contrasting compassion.

verses.text: We raided the Negev of the Cherethites, the territory belonging to Judah, and the Negev of Caleb, and we burned Ziklag with fire.
verses.comment: The Cherethites later become part of David’s elite guard (2 Sam. 8:18). Caleb’s land stands for the faithful inheritance (Josh. 14:13).

verses.text: David said to him, 'Will you lead me down to this raiding party?' He replied, 'Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or deliver me back to my master, and I will take you down to them.'
verses.comment: An oath before God binds the agreement; swearing by God’s name gives moral weight, anticipating the seriousness of Christian vows.

verses.text: When he had led him down, they were spread out over all the land, eating, drinking, and celebrating because of all the great spoil they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from Judah.
verses.comment: The enemy's careless feasting leads to their downfall—a pattern repeated throughout Scripture (Dan. 5:1-6).

verses.text: David struck them down from dawn until evening of the next day. Not a man of them escaped except four hundred young men who rode off on camels and fled.
verses.comment: David’s victory is complete—again, the number four hundred recurs, showing even the mighty can have a remnant, much like Israel itself.

verses.text: David recovered all that the Amalekites had taken, and David rescued his two wives.
verses.comment: The restoration theme parallels Christ’s mission to restore all that was lost (Luke 19:10).

verses.text: Nothing was missing, young or old, sons or daughters, spoil or anything they had taken. David brought back everything.
verses.comment: A type of perfect restoration—hinting at the fullness of salvation and the completeness of Christ’s redemptive work (John 6:39).

verses.text: David also took all the flocks and herds, and his men drove them ahead of the other livestock, saying, “This is David’s spoil.”
verses.comment: By assigning the spoil to David, the people acknowledge his kingship, foreshadowing the honor due to the anointed one.

verses.text: Then David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow him and had been left at the brook Besor. They came out to meet David and those with him, and David greeted them with peace.
verses.comment: David’s greeting (Hebrew 'shalom') anticipates the peace of Christ given to all in the Church, regardless of outward ability (John 20:19).

verses.text: But all the wicked and worthless men among those who went with David said, 'Because they did not go with us, we will not give them any of the spoil we have recovered, except for each man’s wife and children, that they may lead them away and depart.'
verses.comment: Human pride resists generosity, setting up David’s just policy in the next verse which emphasizes unity in the body.

verses.text: But David said, 'You shall not do so, my brothers, with what the LORD has given us. He has preserved us and delivered into our hand the raiding party that came against us.'
verses.comment: David recognizes that all victory comes from God and insists on sharing with all. This models generosity and the spiritual principle of every member being one in the people of God (Eph. 4:16).

verses.text: 'Who will listen to you in this matter? For as his share is who goes down into the battle, so shall his share be who stays by the baggage; they shall share alike.'
verses.comment: David institutes a rule of equal sharing. This principle would echo later in the New Testament regarding unity, co-laboring, and the communion of the faithful (cf. Matt. 20:1-16; 1 Cor. 12:12).

verses.text: And so it was from that day forward; he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel to this day.
verses.comment: A binding law is made—showing how divinely guided leadership shapes the spiritual order and stewardship of God’s people.

verses.text: When David came to Ziklag, he sent some of the spoil to the elders of Judah, his friends, saying, 'Here is a present for you from the spoil of the enemies of the LORD.'
verses.comment: David’s act of sharing bounty with elders established bonds of charity and mutual support, signaling the importance of maintaining unity among God’s people through acts of generosity—a spiritual inheritance that echoes in later Church practice (Rom. 15:26-27).

verses.text: He sent it to those in Bethel, Ramoth of the Negev, and Jattir;
verses.comment: These were Levitical and Judahite towns, demonstrating David’s concern for both priestly and lay communities.

verses.text: to those in Aroer, Siphmoth, and Eshtemoa;
verses.comment: Eshtemoa was a town given to priests, again highlighting David’s special regard for spiritual leadership in Israel.

verses.text: to those in Racal, the towns of the Jerahmeelites, and the towns of the Kenites;
verses.comment: David’s distribution reaches far, fostering loyalty and gratitude among various allied groups, including the Kenites who were friendly to Israel.

verses.text: to those in Hormah, Bor-ashan, Athach,
verses.comment: Hormah was a city once destroyed by Israel’s enemies, now benefiting from David’s victory, symbolizing conquering evil through faithfulness.

verses.text: and to those in Hebron, and to all the places where David and his men had roamed.
verses.comment: Hebron will soon be David’s royal city. The mention of 'all the places where David and his men had roamed' recalls the breadth of his ministry and the foundational unity later seen in the one flock gathered by the true King (John 10:16).
